info.name: ForgeRock Cloud APIs (Apr 2019)
info.description:
The ForgeRock Identity Cloud includes two sets of APIs: * Authentication APIs: Allows you to authenticate users into your apps. * Management APIs: Supports management of objects such as users. Note: Many of the REST calls in this collection require that you have set up a web app, using the steps described in our documentation on SDKs: Web App (Node.js SDK). Some of these REST calls include scopes, which specify access rights as described in our documentation on scopes. Use that guidance to set up the scopes property in your Postman collection. The scopes that you specify in REST calls should be included in relevant apps. When you create an app in the UI, you can identify and update these scopes under the "API Scopes" tab.

This collecition is set up with the following environment: ForgeRock Environment Vars 0.3. You can use the environment to pre-populate your REST calls. For more information, see the following section on REST APIs. Some REST calls are configured to "pre-populate" others; for example, when you run the POST Get Web App Token - Password Grant call, the output pre-populates values for userAccessToken, refreshToken, and userIdToken. All example responses are based on cURL.

item.name: Authentication APIs
Get Web App Token - Password Grant

urlencoded.description: As allowed by your web app

request.description:
Requires credentials for an existing user. This call sets up a base64-encoded value for the web app via `Basic Auth` under authentication, using the Client ID and Client Secret for the web app.

Returns tokens specific to a user:
* access_token
* refresh_token
* id_token

You'll need these tokens for other REST calls for the specific user. In your Postman app, under the Test tab for this REST call, you'll see code that captures these tokens as input for corresponding environment variables. 

When you include scopes, make sure they correspond to active scopes for your app.

response.name: Get Web App Token - Password Grant

urlencoded.value: me.read me.update me.update-password password-policy.read user.reset-password user.recover-username user.create user.read openid profile

response.body:
{
    "access_token": "{{userAccessToken}}",
    "refresh_token": "{{userRefreshToken}}",
    "scope": "openid me.update profile user.recover-username user.read me.read user.create password-policy.read me.update-password user.reset-password",
    "id_token": "{{userIdToken}}",
    "token_type": "Bearer",
    "expires_in": 3599
}

request.description: Returns end user info. Requires an access_token created for the specific user, set as the *Bearer* token. You can acquire a user access_token from the Get Web App Token - Password Grant REST call.

query.description: Consent will redirect to this url with access_token & additional response parameters

request.description: This REST call assumes that you've set up a Web App as described in the following documentation: Web App (Node.js SDK). Use this call to find the authorization code grant type in the POST Get Web App Token REST calls. To find the authorization code, you'll first need a Location URL. Run the REST call in one of the following two ways: * Run the REST call in the CLI in verbose mode * Review the REST output in the Postman console (It's OK if you get a 302 Found result. You can still get the information in one of the two ways noted.) Open to the browser of your choice. * Navigate to the Location URL. * Open the developer mode for your browser. * Navigate to your network monitor. * Log in as a regular user. * Find the entry with `callback?code`. * Look for the parameters for that entry. * Find and copy the `code` entry associated with the `query string`. That is your authorization code. You'll need that `code` in the **Get Web App Token** REST calls.

item.name: Get M2M (Service) token - Client Credentials Grant

request.description:
Requires a Client ID and Client Secret for the service app. This call sets up a base64-encoded value for the service app via `Basic Auth` under authentication, using these values.

Returns the following tokens specific to the service app:
* access_token

You'll need this token for other REST calls for the service app.

response.name: Get M2M (Service) token - Client Credentials Grant

urlencoded.value: app.read email-template.read password-policy.read user.reset-password user.recover-username user.create user.read user.update

request.description: Retrieves configuration data, including: * Endpoints. * Default scopes. For a full list, see our documentation on Scopes. * Encryption and digital signature algorithms. * Supported claims, such as `address` and `phone_number`.

item.description: Supports authentication of users to access apps. Some Authentication API endpoints support creation of app and user access tokens. You can then use those access tokens in the Management API. You can use these REST calls to build authentication into your apps. To take full advantage of the Management API, include appropriate scopes in requests to authorization endpoints. The Authentication API then includes the scope in the output access token. For more information, see our documentation on scopes.

header.description: Specifies a URI that may access the resource. For requests without credentials, the server may specify '*' as a wildcard, thereby allowing any origin to access the resource.

header.name: Content-Length
header.description: The length of the response body in octets (8-bit bytes)

header.name: Content-Type
header.description: The mime type of this content

header.name: Date
header.description: The date and time that the message was sent

header.name: ETag

item.description:
Manage the global password policy for users of the tenant. Use the GET Password Policy call to review the current password policy, in JSON format. You can then use the output to format your desired password policy, through the Set Password Policy call.

- The password age is set in `days`.
- The password lock duration is set in `minutes`.
- You can disable numeric options such as `maxPasswordAge` by setting them to 0.

For a more complete discussion, see our documentation on [Password Policies](https://developer-cloud.forgerock.com/quickstarts/password-policies/).

request.description:
Gets a list of available email templates. You'll see output:

* In JSON Format
* Classified by template `type` and `id`


For more information, see our documentation on [Email Templates](https://developer-cloud.forgerock.com/quickstarts/email-templates/).

To send a test email via REST, review the output for the desired template `type` or `id`. Include that information in the POST Send Test Email REST call.

item.description: The /hosted-pages endpoint allows you to list and add/modify pages to host on your app.

The Management API allows you to manage objects (including users).With your apps, you can exchange a client ID and secret for an access token and call the API using the token.  

Some of these apps require the access_token for your ui-{{tenantName}}.forgeblocks.com app. You can get this token from the developer console for your browser, as the `Authorization: Bearer` token under Request Headers.
